author: @elevensiestoteatime
text: YES OLAYEMI the sexism in the "girls develop earlier" thing! Science is not free of bias- sexism racism homophobia ableism etc are deeply entrenched in medicalism and academia! üîäüîäüîä

replies.author: @ookamiblade6318
replies.text: Agreed a large part of that research that isn‚Äôt mentioned is that part of why girls ‚Äòdevelop‚Äô faster is that they are expected to. They are expected to participate in household chores earlier, which gives them responsibility earlier, which means they‚Äôve been socialized to learn from authority earlier, which preps them for learning faster.

replies.author: @frostyfrenchtoast
replies.text:
@ookamiblade6318 social development is still a world away from biological development - social factors wouldn‚Äôt alter your very biology. Females do develop their brains faster than males and reach maturity quicker, this is still a fact at this point. 

Whatever reasons for that in nature are largely gone though, humans are just so far removed from our natural environment that referring strictly to naturalistic traits to justify saying stuff to girls and young women is still very weird and gross. Anyone who appeals to that in reference to talking dirty towards a girl is a complete creep

replies.author: @xbabu142x
replies.text:
@ookamiblade6318 
Aye. Basically the skinny of it being neurobiologically that this responsibility and work causes girls to optimize their neuronal connections before boys. For anyone wanting to read into this btw: [Scientists at Newcastle University in the U.K. have discovered that girls tend to optimize brain connections earlier than boys. The researchers conclude that this may explain why females generally mature faster in certain cognitive and emotional areas than males during childhood and adolescence. The new study was published on December 19, 2013, in Cerebral Cortex.]

replies.text: Thank you

replies.text: ‚Äã@ookamiblade6318  I agree

replies.author: @ookamiblade6318
replies.text: @smelly1060 yeah, it doesn‚Äôt always mean, but when you find a correlation you look for a causation, and this causation is what the research found. Correlation: pickpocketing and ice-cream sales correlate. Correlation doesn‚Äôt mean causation: ice-cream doesn‚Äôt pick your pocket. The causation: ice-cream is frequently sold in tourist locations tourists are easier targets for pickpockets.

replies.author: @lwitte8857
replies.text:
For a person that KNOWS that they are intelligent, having not learned something yet is not a sign of weakness or a ding against their intellect. It is an opportunity to learn and grow. 

I am in school to be an occupational therapist and the best mentors I have had have been a wealth of knowledge but have also been fully comfortable saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure, do your own research and let me know what you find‚Äù. 
This mentality is actually an important part of improving health outcomes. Having the confidence and depth of knowledge to effectively convey what you do know AND the humility (and TIME) to say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, let me research that‚Äù when you don‚Äôt or even ‚Äúlet me double check‚Äù if you are uncertain. Knowing enough to understand that you have only seen a small part of what‚Äôs out there (Dunning-Kruger effect) AND being able to admit it helps people be life long learners and better medical professionals.

replies.author: @JDBaldBabyVance
replies.text: I don't want to downplay sexism or the devaluation of women among men, that is real and should be talked about, but I feel like this comment (save for the not all to leave deniability) underestimates how many guys might rightfully recognize men and women play two different societal games that gives them unique challenges, and might feel like a women might not understand them on a man level the way another man would. I imagine there are many women who feel the same way about the idea of having a male therapist and I assume we wouldn't jump to attributing that to not respecting men as therapists or people. I'm nonbinary, but I am male, and I recognize when I move through the world many people will look at me, assume man, and treat me thusly, and for that reason I'd probably also prefer to get therapy from a man who knows what's it's like existing in the world as a male and how men are treated in ways women aren't likely to fully understand. That said, if I couldn't find a male therapist I'm not wholly opposed to a woman therapist, something would be better than nothing if I felt I needed psychiatric help.

author: @kaleb9375
text:
I was really happy to see Olay and Antoinette push back against the "fact" ( I've no clue where this idea originates or what sort of information it's steeped in) that "girls mature faster than boys", because it's always seemed like a nasty trap to me. Like, what are you insinuating when you say that? That boys are just innately incapable of having emotional intelligence on par with girls? It's a very odd way to suggest nature over nurture. As though emotional/social intelligence isn't something that needs to be taught to *everybody*. Because a lot of people out here, irrespective of their gender or race, tend to be emotionally inept. I don't know, it's always seemed like a weak way to justify a man's emotional incompetence. 

This is sort of on topic, but it reminds me of the time my cousin readily admitted he intentionally did not teach his 2 sons how to cook or clean because it would be something "their wives would take care of". It's this sort of gender essentialism that only seems to serve men and put more burden on women to be competent in all these facets of personhood.

I hope this comment made sense! As always, love the show and all the input the guests have to offer

replies.author: @ammonstyles5417
replies.text:
You spit nothing but factsü´°

I'm really close with my little cousin, who has a tenuous relationship with her family. One of the biggest talking points between us is that she SHOULD expect more from the men and boys in her life, and that her non-cooking trifling ass dad teaching her that she should be the emotional punching bag is WRONG. I get hot everytime we talk and she mentions how they keep referring to her as a "woman" when trying to justify why she should understand the neglectful men in her life, or why she should take up emotional or laborious duties that should be reserved for consenting adult women.

She hasn't even turned 17 yet. You put it perfectly‚úäüèæ

replies.author: @Wesleigh11
replies.text:
Yo that later logic always making me so mad.  What do you mean " the men don't have to learn cooking and cleaning? Only wives do that?"

Like I was 17 when I overheard one of my Grandpa's friends say something very similar. Even back then I knew that sounded dumb. Probably because I was starting to think about college and will I be going out of state and whatnot. I thought "If that was really true,  What about when I am living on my own? As a bachelor, Won't I still need to cook and clean for myself until I meet a woman to be my wife?" Like it didn't make sense to me to not have those skills.

author: @MarshaManeater
text:
Love the video! I wanted to say that I think we miss an opportunity to talk about how the ideas of success via patriarchy and capitalism harm us ALL when we hone the conversation in on little boys. I don‚Äôt want them to fall out of discussion but as an only child who is also a woman/femme, 
I fit into a lot of these conversations. Not because I‚Äôm read as a boy/man but because these are the lessons being taught to any child being pushed towards the ideals of success in our society. In the case of boys, they‚Äôre pushed that way because under patriarchy they‚Äôre forced to be providers/leaders. For me it was simply because it was understood that once something happens to my parents I‚Äôll be on my own. That‚Äôs why I loved y‚Äôall discussing being able to see yourself across gender lines. Being able to see myself in men, helped me understand how deeply the patriarchy can affect anyone concerned with power and success no matter their gender.

author: @ChristopherSadlowski
text:
Wow, I've never heard someone say, "I see myself in women as a man." At least I don't remember hearing a man say that out loud. I'm sure many men feel this way but our society prevents them from being open about that. I'm a man who can see myself in girls and women, and in other men too. It's made my life so much bigger and more expansive having this kind of...empathy? Is this a kind of empathy? I don't know; chat can correct me because I'm sure that's not the right word. Anyway, let's teach boys and men to see their strength, power, and whatever else in the women they meet. It's not THE solution to misogyny, but it is A solution, and a easy place to start in my opinion. Admiring a woman/femme doesn't make a boy or man "a girl" or worse..."a gay"! üòÑ 

::sigh:: We have so much damn work to do...

Ive heard stuff from they are feminizing men from 16yo teens to you dont want your partner to be independent from you from 19yo teens. I always challenge their thought process. And maybe its due to the youth but they end up getting so close but ending it with a shrug and give up before they realize the problem.

I've never heard a good thing about Akademiks. I think the first time i saw him was him being weird talking to our about Hasan. Then i found out he was Drake's strongest soldier. Then i found out FD hated him about as much as Drake it seemed. Now I'm hearing predators do indeed move in flocks. [Scientists at Newcastle University in the U.K. have discovered that girls tend to optimize brain connections earlier than boys. The researchers conclude that this may explain why females generally mature faster in certain cognitive and emotional areas than males during childhood and adolescence. The new study was published on December 19, 2013, in Cerebral Cortex.]

author: @NotSoCivilEngineer
text:
33:00 I‚Äôm aware of this research, but I‚Äôm also aware of research from 2021 that showed that, in the US, gay men have the highest rates out of all combinations of binary gender and sexual orientation of obtaining both undergraduate degrees (52% compared to the national average of 36%) and advanced degrees (6% compared to the national average of about 4%).

That same study found gay men in each of the four major racial and ethnic groups recognized on the US census, in aggregate, academically outperformed the straight men within the same racial/ethnic groups.

There is some interesting exploration for potential reasons why this plays out for gay men like this, but it still is interesting because I have no reason to believe that gay men are somehow inherently more academically inclined than straight men.

author: @aaronstewart3352
text: This isn‚Äôt a trauma dump, bc I‚Äôve done the work to come to terms w it, but I was molested by my stepdad for years in high school. The single largest issue I had to work on through therapy is the fact that, bc I felt this physical imperative and drive towards sex as a teenage kid, I spent a large amount of time wrestling with the idea that it was something that I wanted, or that I ‚Äúasked for it‚Äù (spoiler: I didn‚Äôt). Growing up in a very small, conservative, and homophobic, pro abstinence area, I had no one to talk to or work through those feelings, which made me vulnerable to abuse, and that‚Äôs what predators prey on. They rely on ignorance and the power dynamic. Education is fundamental. Letting your boy explore their feelings, letting them know that it‚Äôs safe to be open about sex and sexuality, letting them know about boundaries, letting them know about bodily autonomy, is so crucial to making sure that they don‚Äôt fall victim to predators. I really appreciated this discussion.

author: @mahaliahlittle1914
text: I appreciate your channel and the conversations you facilitate! I just wanted to comment that some of the comments from the commenters (a) coddled men‚Äôs decisions - for example, you don‚Äôt have to know about patriarchy to necessarily know, for example, you‚Äôre hurting someone repeatedly. Ak and Boosie and Tory are not teenage boys that are seeking out motivational content that end up getting sucked in because they‚Äôre impressionable. I also felt like some of the comments about girls maturing faster or being more emotionally intelligent were a little essentialist. Girls are given responsibility at an early age - for cleaning, helping others, care taking etc, and these things manifest as seeming ‚Äúmore mature.‚Äù I really appreciated your comment recentering socialization in the conversation! Thank you! Boys don‚Äôt get much direction as you mentioned (left to their own devices but also taught to routinely repress their emotions), but they‚Äôre also, either directly or implicitly incentivized to pursue their own interests. Girls only seem to develop faster because they‚Äôre socialized to be more considerate. Still a great convo! And again, I think socialization is the big baddie in everything, not innate gendered traits

author: @FullElvenCosplay
text:
The crazy thing, and I say this from experience of raising my 4 little boys, boys can easily be emotionally mature. It's wild how emotionally mature they become when you let them not only feel their feelings, but start helping them process what they're feeling, why, and being okay with feeling negative emotions without feeling 'unsafe' about feeling them. Letting them know it's okay to need a moment to breathe because they're angry before they talk about what made them angry. Letting them know it's okay to cry and be sad, even if it's something no one feels is worth crying over. It's worth crying over because it's important to them. 

Like...my oldest will be 16 this year, and he's been standing up and starting conversations since he was 6 about things with peers. He's called out friends for racism and sexism and bullying, about how we 'shouldn't play guns, they're not toys'. He's been so comfortable talking about his feelings and even telling me when I've messed up. And all my kids have followed that path too. 

And all I did was be patient and talk to them. Boys are every bit as able to be emotionally mature as girls are. We're a big neurodivergent family, so maybe that's why we have those tools to work though it, cause Autism and ADHD and anxiety, but yeah.

author: @jkclark5204
text:
Whenever you see a serious problem and propose radical change, someone immediately gets nervous and wants to shut it down.

The concept that "girls mature faster" isn't just about physical attributes. It IS about our educational system, it's reinforcement of patriarchy, and the unexamined biases of even the most well-intentioned of educators. It may be that boys need the extra time and attention for emotional development.

Like it or not, schools are doing a LOT of the work we conventionally think parents should do. We should consider changing that  system, drastically, to adjust for the real world conditions, not what we want it to be. It may be that boys need extra time for emotional regulation and expression. (Of course, our government is in the process of destroying our educational system right now, so let me shut up...)

text: The kid is 15, not 16. Ak has been temporally banned from twitch several times, not permanently banned and reinstated several times.

author: @BeingMr.Whitty
text:
Low Key - I didn't know anything about AK until I watched him cover the Diddy and then Drake stuff BUT Ak is a totally West Indian and so I understand him. He's a typical West Indian man who's gonna make as much money off dumb American society and he doesn't care how people feel about him doing it. I respect it because I see how African Americans like to gatekeep EVERYTHING and try to control who gets into hip hop etc and yet outside of Joe Budden AK is top tier. He actually does research, he actually sits and talks with people, he's very transparent. Whereas a lot of these dudes are Snoop Dogs. Everybody loves them but they voting Trump and doing weirdo stuff behind closed doors. Can he say weird things YES but I'm sorry until they take Joe Budden down for his long list of bad behaviors I'm watching him for entertainment like everybody else. 

Kendrick said there aren't enough and there aren't! Dudes aint solid these days so not expecting AK to be. (insert shrug emoji)

replies.author: @ADubbs-fd8xf
replies.text: I'm just curious, why do you think African-Americans are gatekeeping Hip-Hop from other Black folks from other backgrounds? Also, even if you do think that that is happening, how does that excuse AK being a creep?

replies.author: @kamikazemind327
replies.text: @ADubbs-fd8xfthe whataboutism is DISGRACEFUL I can not.

replies.author: @staciegreene2262
replies.text: Why can‚Äôt we control what we started ? Everyone else control their own thing . Make that make sense ! When we say ‚Äúnah, we don‚Äôt like yall doing that , that‚Äôs our thing‚Äù . Everyone gets so offended , it‚Äôs weird . Gatekeeping is what keep a culture in tact . I‚Äôm not mad at anyone for not wanting to share/dilute their culture. See yall aren‚Äôt used to MULTIPLE ethnicities wanting to take from your culture. Until that happens to your people , you would never understand the importance of gatekeeping !!

author: @KindnessKillsNONDO
text: 3:48 double edged sword. On one hand it's okay to bully women but if you bully men they will defend themselves. On the other hand it's okay to not love girls but it's not okay to love boys. I am genuinely confused as to when the outrage at male banter became so quickly accepted as infact toxic. If anything could have been dismissed as "boys will be boys", it should have been this. I wonder if Diddy has something to do with why men are on the shallow end of the water and indirectly addressing their pain. We look forward to them swimming.

author: @ruetoo
text:
As a multiracial gay 24 year old,¬†
I completely agree with the gay vs alpha male complex in gaming and media. As a young boy, with an alpha male brother I was honestly traumatized with the alpha male complex. Gaming was a big one, I was terrified by male spaces like playing violent games with violent game video chats. Always homophobic, graphic and bullying each other. I was never accepted into male spaces as a kid in the 2000s.
Also the grooming with men on YouTube reminds me of Shane Dawson. I was his demographic at the time, preteen/ teen boys. He made racist, homophobic, graphic and sexual content for humor didn't come out as gay until much later in his career. His videos invited a really weird energy in the space with for a young kid growing up.
Technology has affected my generation as the "anxious generation" because we saw graphic, sexual and explicit content as children that we have to heal from.¬†We were anxious as children from our environments. History repeats itself truly.
I love Kevin's idea of boys starting school 2 years later. As a five year old, I was not ready for the environments I was in. Bullying, social norms, authority (who some also follow these ideals). If you're not apart of the norm you played alone or pushed to aggressive male play like sports (don't even get me started lol).
INVENT IN BOYS BEFORE "IT TOO LATE" (it's never too late)
So we don't keep repeating this cycle.

replies.author: @ADubbs-fd8xf
replies.text: I'm definitely curious about the whole having boys start school later thing, I haven't read much about it. My knee jerk reaction is to be against it, but there's clearly a problem with how boy children are educated so I'm definitely open to it, even though I feel like it could have some unfortunate consequences.

author: @dameluz5228
text: So I think Petit Blanq Kevin is onto something with regards to educating boys; that being said, i started school (in DR) before age 2 (i walked early and my brain developed fast i guess) so we should def apply a post gendered-binary approach to early childhood education..üëÅü™¨üëÅ
